data.title: Error: connect ETIMEDOUT 52.216.226.96:443
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.15.0
- OS Version: os x ei capitan 10.11.6

./scripts/npm.sh install

```
/Users/liangzeng/Downloads/vscode/node_modules/electron-mksnapshot/download-mksnapshot.js:16
  if (error != null) throw error
                     ^

Error: connect ETIMEDOUT 52.216.226.96:443
    at Object.exports._errnoException (util.js:1026:11)
    at exports._exceptionWithHostPort (util.js:1049:20)
    at TCPConnectWrap.afterConnect [as oncomplete] (net.js:1136:14)
npm WARN optional SKIPPING OPTIONAL DEPENDENCY: windows-foreground-love@0.1.0 (node_modules/windows-foreground-love):
npm WARN notsup SKIPPING OPTIONAL DEPENDENCY: Unsupported platform for windows-foreground-love@0.1.0: wanted {"os":"win32","arch":"any"} (current: {"os":"darwin","arch":"x64"})
npm WARN optional SKIPPING OPTIONAL DEPENDENCY: windows-mutex@0.2.0 (node_modules/windows-mutex):
npm WARN notsup SKIPPING OPTIONAL DEPENDENCY: Unsupported platform for windows-mutex@0.2.0: wanted {"os":"win32","arch":"any"} (current: {"os":"darwin","arch":"x64"})

npm ERR! code ELIFECYCLE
npm ERR! errno 1
npm ERR! electron-mksnapshot@1.6.0 install: `node ./download-mksnapshot.js`
npm ERR! Exit status 1
npm ERR! 
npm ERR! Failed at the electron-mksnapshot@1.6.0 install script.
npm ERR! This is probably not a problem with npm. There is likely additional logging output above.

npm ERR! A complete log of this run can be found in:
npm ERR!     /Users/liangzeng/.electron-gyp/.npm/_logs/2017-07-30T01_13_40_555Z-debug.log

```

data.title: Scrollbar slider on minimap isn't active after click on the track place
data.body:
Scrollbar slider on minimap doesn't become dragged by the click on the free track place like it does on simple slider [with disabled minimap].

- VSCode Version: 1.14.2
- OS Version: Microsoft Windows [Version 10.0.15063]

Steps to Reproduce:



1. Open any document large enough to have free track place on the scrollbar
2. Enable minimap
3. Mousedown on the free track space of the scrollbar
4. Try to drag mouse (not releasing the button from the previous item)\
Result: slider should be dragged on simple scrollbar, but it isn't. It's not dragged until you release the mouse and grab it again. On the normal scrollbar slider becomes dragged during the first click on free track space.

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: VS Code Helper taking too much CPU power

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->

- OS Version: macOS 10.12.5

data.title: TSServer crashes not being able to resolve path correctly
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.14.2 (cb82febafda0c8c199b9201ad274e25d9a76874e, 2017-07-19T23:22:50.650Z) - OS Version: Darwin x64 16.7.0 - Extensions: disabled I have these logs that don't make sense to me, maybe someone can help me out here? My project looks like this: 

root
  |--scripts
  |  |--debug.js <- here tsserver crashes, and it's not able to work properly
  |--modules
  |  |--sensor
  |     |-tsconfig.json
  |--tsconfig.json
And as soon as I add that root `tsconfig.json`, tsserver starts crashing! The part that I don't understand is why it cannot resolve my root `tsconfig.json` file at `info 11` in the log! **When I run tsserver from my workspace**

Info 1    request: {"seq":0,"type":"request","command":"configure","arguments":{"hostInfo":"vscode"}}

data.title: Sync configs
data.body: I love vscode, but everytime I have to install it on a new computer I always have to download all extensions and make the same config. I would love to have an account to login into vscode and have all my extensions and config synced around with all my devices, just like Google Chrome.

data.title: TAB not working
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.15.0-insider - OS Version: WINDOWS 10 x64 Steps to Reproduce: Open an HTML file or create and save a new one Type any tag, for example div Hit "tab" -- it should display
Same thing with Emmet shortcuts, and in SCSS files as well. Nothing happens. This used to work, I believe it worked in yesterday's Insider build. Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Feature request: Add option to reload extension
data.body:
feature-request:
I think it would be nice to have the option to reload extensions. Currently I do it by disabling and re-enabling the extension, which is not practical and requires two window reloads (one after disabling and one after enabling the extension).

The reason why I did this in the first place is because of a bug in the extension itself that made the extension stop working and the only option was to reload the extension.

data.title: Multiple prompts to exclude large folders
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.15.0-insider (0e7546c978fa1b62dbf36f07a77d1b9a4241d6f7, 2017-07-28T11:23:06.089Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.16232
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
vscode-eslint|dba|1.2.11
coldfusion|ili|0.0.10
wordcount|ms-|0.1.0


I just opened a large(ish) project and I got a prompt from VSC to configure excludes to enable project-wide JS/TS features. So I clicked "Configure Excludes", on the file that popped up I simply saved it and carried on. 

Then I got the prompt again.
And again. 3 times now. 

And I'm pretty sure jsconfig.json already existed.

Ok, I can confirm that if I switch to another project and then come back, the warnings come back too. So there's something about this project that is tripping up VSC. If it helps, this is the project:

https://github.com/cfjedimaster/Serverless-Examples

and this is the existing jsconfig.json

{
    "compilerOptions":{
        "target": "es6"
    },
    "exclude": [
        "node_modules"
    ]
}


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. 
2.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes/No

data.title: Unable to set bitmap font
data.body:
VSCode Version: 1.14.2
Commit cb82febafda0c8c199b9201ad274e25d9a76874e
Date 2017-07-19T23:26:08.116Z
Shell 1.6.6
Renderer 56.0.2924.87
Node 7.4.0

OS Version: Fedora 26: 4.11.9-300.fc26.x86_64

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Set a bitmap font in settings: `"editor.fontFamily": "'xos4 Terminus', monospace",`
2. Save file and notice font doesn't change (even after restart).

Note that `monospace` is also aliased to `xos4 Terminus` by fontconfig and other applications such as chromium and xfce4-terminal correctly pick it up:
```
$ fc-match "xos4 Terminus"
ter-112n.pcf.gz: "xos4 Terminus" "Regular"
$ fc-match monospace
ter-112n.pcf.gz: "xos4 Terminus" "Regular"
```

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Bug in auto indent of <style> tag in html-css emmet.
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.14.2
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Make html file and type 
```
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
    
</head>
<body>
    
</body>
</html>
```

2. Type "style" between <head> tag and press Tab key. It will produce <style></style> and the position of cursor will be in the middle of the open tag and the close tag.
3. Press Enter key.

The result should be, ( "||" symbol means current cursor position)

```
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
    <style>
        ||
    </style>
</head>
<body>
    
</body>
</html>
```

However, the result is
```
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
    <style>
        ||</style>
</head>
<body>
    
</body>
</html>
```

And when I press Enter key again, the result is
```
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
    <style>
        
||</style>
</head>
<body>
    
</body>
</html>
```


<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes/No

data.title: Javascript intellisense and ctrl + click navigation is not working for JavaScript Object annotation with module.exports
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.12
- OS Version: MacOS sierra 10.12.5

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a first.js Javascript file with following code:

// In this file create an object p with two properties "hello" and "world". and export the object using module.exports like following code.i.e. one property with direct assignment and another is added after main object is created.

```
let p = {
    "world":"world"
};
p.hello = "hello";
module.exports = p;

```
2. In the second file, import the first.js file.

but intellisense is not showing "hello" property. I am able to see the "world" property in intellisense menu. Following code is attached.

```
const first = require("./first");

//Able to see world property in intellisense menu.
console.log(first.world);

//Not able to see hello property in intellisense menu.
console.log(first.hello);

```
3. Same issue is with Javascript functions as well.

4. Also while clicking on the "world" property in the second file, it can navigate to first file. But it is not working with "hello" property.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

When I hover over a method or function, it shows he info that is not correct.
For example, in the given part of node.js code
```
form.parse(req, function (formerror, fields, files) {
```
When I hovered over the function paramaters in some of the previous versions of vs code, they showed them more detailed and correct like this on hovering
```
formerror(paramater) : error /* I am sorry if my syntax of displaying the hover is incorrect*/
fields(paramater) : Fields
files(paramater) : Files
```
But in this update and in the previous one, it only shows "any" as type on hovering. I have even updated the typescript version by changing the typescript.tsdk setting as shown in the screenshot
![screenshot](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/26246421/28743762-9d836250-746f-11e7-8037-30f637290dd7.png)

data.title: Hyper terminal (external) using BASH shell opens to user home, rather than VSCode's working directory
data.body:
**Summary**

When using [Windows Subsystem for Linux](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/commandline/wsl/about) (bash) as the shell for [Hyper](https://hyper.is/) terminal, `ctrl+shift+c` defaults to the user's home instead of the current folder. (Presumably because it wants a path starting with `/mnt/c/...`)

Hyper+bash opens correctly from Windows explorer if you right click and select "Open Hyper here", and bash.exe (by itself) opens correctly from VSCode as external terminal. The problem only occurs when Hyper+bash is set as the external terminal (see steps to reproduce.)

--- 

**System Info**
- VSCode Version: Code 1.14.2 (cb82febafda0c8c199b9201ad274e25d9a76874e, 2017-07-19T23:34:09.706Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.15063

- Extensions: 
Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
ng-template|Ang|0.1.4
path-intellisense|chr|1.4.2
bracket-pair-colorizer|Coe|0.10.7
githistory|don|0.2.2
EditorConfig|Edi|0.9.4
tslint|eg2|0.17.0
vscode-yarn|gam|1.2.0
Angular2|joh|2.4.0
vscode-scss|mrm|0.6.2
csharp|ms-|1.11.0
PowerShell|ms-|1.4.1
debugger-for-chrome|msj|3.1.6
angular2-inline|nat|0.0.17
material-icon-theme|PKi|2.0.11
json-template|sto|0.3.1

---

**Steps to Reproduce**:

1. Install [Hyper](https://hyper.is/) and configure `.hyper.js` for use with bash
```
config: {
  ...
  shell: 'C:\\Windows\\System32\\bash.exe',
  shellArgs: [],
  ...
}
```
2. Open vscode, edit User Settings
3. Set your Hyper.exe as external terminal (replace <username> for your own install dir)
```
"terminal.external.windowsExec": "C:\\Users\\<username>\\AppData\\Local\\hyper\\Hyper.exe",
```
4. Launch external terminal (default `ctrl+shift+c`)
5. Note the directory is set to user's home instead of the one open in vscode

Try again with bash alone, and it opens to the correct directory:
```
"terminal.integrated.shell.windows": "C:\\WINDOWS\\Sysnative\\bash.exe",
```

--- 

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Formatting problem with VSCode and JS

`this.create` and `this.data` are not on the same distance from the left border of the screen as you can see.
This is how VS Code arranged them after using format feature.
Why?

![screenshot_1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/26545183/28743510-b168e9e2-745c-11e7-9e25-740c843b1c01.png)

data.title: [css] avoid showing prefixed values as first entries

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Currently, VSCode CSS Autocomplete lists browser prefixed values for CSS properties but I think it should just list the standard properties. 

## Why?

1. No new properties are going to be created with prefixes.
2. It seems like a real good extension usecase. More like a snippet.
3. Most people needing prefixes would actually use autoprefixer or similar tools in build chain to get that part automated.

## Benefits?
- Reduces the maintenance on the language-server side.
- Encourages use of standard properties and using a tool to get prefixes when needed.
- Reduces the amount of options shown in the intellisense list so it's easier to navigate and provides better UX.

## Example
Here the list shows `-ms-` and `-webkit-` prefixed version of values even before the standard value comes in.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/313363/28743309-9b724da6-7464-11e7-8b54-699c3ac8ed56.png)

    at tryModuleLoad (module.js:447:12)
    at Function.Module._load (module.js:439:3)
    at Module.runMain (module.js:605:10)
    at run (bootstrap_node.js:424:7)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Debug [electron-quick-start](https://github.com/electron/electron-quick-start)
2. Debug Main Process

data.title: Ignore external consoles when detecting running terminal process on Windows
data.body:
This PR fixes a bug with terminal process name detection on Windows when an external console is launched with the `start` command.

It takes advantage of the fact that any console in a new window will have a child process of `conhost.exe`.
While going through the child process tree, if a process with a name of `conhost.exe` is detected, the shell two levels up will be re-examined for other child processes.

Because this requires travelling back up to the shell from which the external console was launched, child processes are cached while traversing the tree.

Below is a gif of VS Code with the changes on the left and the current version on the right:

![2017-07-28_23-21-31](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/18223213/28743077-ac9548b4-73f5-11e7-9450-04df9a70a546.gif)

You'll notice that at the end of the gif, the name takes a while to change. This is because with two external shells, the traversal is like this (tree below):

```
|___ powershell.exe
| |___ cmd.exe
| | |___ conhost.exe
| |___ bash.exe
| | |___ conhost.exe
| |___ cmd.exe
```

Go to `powershell.exe`, query child processes, go to `cmd.exe`, query child processes, go to `conhost.exe`, go back to `powershell.exe`, query child processes, go to `bash.exe`, query child processes, go to `conhost.exe`, go back to `powershell.exe`, use cached child processes, go to `cmd.exe`, query child processes, return with `cmd.exe` -
 every single time a terminal title update is requested.

This is a lot of queries. One option to fix this would be to save the pids of the external consoles. However I don't know how Windows recycles pids, and this might flag other perfectly good processes as externally launched. Another option would be to parse this list backwards, but I don't know whether the external processes will always be first.

data.title: F5 debugger for Python does not pick up the fact it's Python3!
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.14.2 (cb82febafda0c8c199b9201ad274e25d9a76874e, 2017-07-19T23:26:08.116Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.10.0-28-generic
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
python|don|0.6.9



---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Run this simple script ("./test.py") and it will fail, showing that it correctly is trying python3:
```
#! /usr/bin/env python3
print( "hello" )
import urllib2
print( "success")

```
2. Press F5 and note it is not stopping, not actually debugging in python3 despite the first line pointing to python3!

data.title: Vscode+Samba: filenames (links) lose their share name in .md viewer
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.14.2
- OS Version: Windows 10 v 1703 (build 15063.483)

Scenario: my source code lives on a linux box, which I export to my local network via a samba share.  I use vscode from a windows box to edit the code in that share.  Most things work just fine with this (with the usual caveats).  However, when viewing a preview of a markdown file, relative links to other documentation files seem to lose the share name, resulting in an error when I try to navigate to them.

Example:
When viewing a markdown preview of `\\MACHINE\dev\devenv\repos\git_tools\git_services\gwbmgr\readme.md` and clicking on a link to `[installation](./doc/installation.md)`, vscode brings up the error:

Unable to open 'installation.md': File not found (\dev\devenv\repos\git_tools\git_services\gwbmgr\doc\installation.md)

I.e. the viewer has lost the share name when trying to resolve the filename.

This isn't a big deal - I'm raising this in case it's a wider issue.

data.title: How do I clear up what appears to be a corrupted environment?
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.14.2
- OS Version: Windows 10 Enterprise - 1703 - 15063.483

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open apparently corrupted folder
2. See that ctrl+space leads to eternal "loading" and that alt-p -> run tasks -> will just sit loading possible tasks forever

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

The way I worked around this problem is that I copied my entire folder into a new location and then opened the new location and VS Code works like a champ.

And yes, I really did repo this with --disable-extensions. Even with --disable-extensions submitted the 'corrupt' location won't work and the new one will in terms of things like intellisense.

What appears to be happening is that during our tests we create a directory test/testRoot and in there are actual Node projects which contain node_modules which contain a reference to the project we are developing. Now, not being completely stupid, I early on added testRoot as an entry to tesconfig.json/exclude. But somehow VS Code is still "seeing" testRoot and especially when I use npm link (which presumably creates a loop from the project entry in node_modules in testRoot back to the production project) things break. What I have done is added include to our tsconfig.json and specify our src and test directory and I have hoisted testRoot out of the test directory and made it its own directory (it has, btw, always been in .gitignore). So far that seems to have fixed the issue.

So the bug seems to be that even though the testRoot directory was in tsconfig.json/exclude, in some way VS Code appears to be 'seeing' it, even if possibly just enumerating directory contents and that causes it to fail somehow. But why was it looking in that directory at all when it was on the exclude list?

data.title: TypeScript formatter -- insertSpaceBeforeFunctionParenthesis -- fails when generic arguments are present
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

- VSCode Version: 1.14.2
- OS Version: Windows 10

```ts
function sample1<A, B, C> (a: A, b?: B, c?: C) {
}

function sample2 (a: any, b?: any, c?: any) {
}
```

When typing a completion character (the closing curly braces in the above example), the autoformatter removes the space before the function parentheses in `sample1` but not in `sample2`, with the former leading to linting complaints in my code.

My settings:

```json
{
  "typescript.format.insertSpaceBeforeFunctionParenthesis": true,
  "typescript.format.insertSpaceAfterFunctionKeywordForAnonymousFunctions": true
}
```

Generic arguments affect both of the above settings.

data.title: Add rename action to terminal quickpick and keybindings
No way to show Problems Panel, only toggle
data.body:
Our extension wants to show the problems panel (only the 1st time a particular issue occurs, to give visibility to the problem so users don't miss it), but calling the command workbench.actions.view.problems causes the problems panel to disappear if it's already showing. Can you provide a way to show and not just toggle the Problem panel (or get the view state so we can skip the toggle if it's already showing).

Without this improved API, we're going to do a showInformationMessage with a "Toggle Problems Panel" button, which is obviously not an ideal experience.
